description:
Domestic helper Piang Ngaih Don, 24, weighed just 24kg when she died. An autopsy uncovered 31 recent scars and 47 external injuries scattered all over Piang's body. 

Over 9 months, Gaiyathiri Murugayan, 40, repeatedly abused Piang. The latter was deprived of food and water and lost 15 kg in the process. She had no privacy, being forced to shower or relieve herself with the toilet door open while Gaiyathiri and her mother Prema S Naraynasamy watched.

She had to wear many layers of face masks as she went about her work in the house, because Gaiyathiri found her unhygienic and did not want to look at her face.

On the day Piang died, Gaiyathiri had rained blows on her, bashed her head with a detergent bottle, and Prema allegedly punched the worker‚Äôs neck and choked her. 

Piang was so weak that she could barely get up from the toilet floor, but the women did not stop their abuse...

Read on. Click on the link in bio @todayonline

comments: This news is so saddening. She came to work to seek better life for her 3 yo son, only to be abused & died under the hands of a pair of mother & daughter.

comments: There should be a campaign here in Singapore on the rights of domestic helpers. They need our trust and respect. The more we trust them, the more loyalty and good service we get back from them. Shame that we have these kind of employers in this country. Why not every agent employ adhoc officers to do random check on each and every one of their domestic helpers biweekly for the first 6 months. Make a checklist and private interviews with them. So they have a space to express themselves. Do medical checkups or anything such.

comments: Welcome to Singapore, where they dont give shit to Strike etc. As long you dont have legal license to conduct, you make shit, you get shit. End of story.
description:
In a statement issued by the group alleged to have assembled illegally, it said that they were a group of students and supporters staging a peaceful demonstration to call on Education Minister Lawrence Wong to end discrimination against the LGBTQ+ community in schools.

The police said in a statement on Tuesday that the group outside MOE‚Äôs headquarters had allegedly gathered even though they did not have a permit to carry out the public assembly.

Yesterday (Jan 26) afternoon, images circulating on social media showed five young people outside the building along Buona Vista Drive holding up placards, a rainbow-coloured pride flag and a transgender flag with pale-pink and blue stripes.

Recently, an 18-year-old junior college student alleged that the ministry had prevented her from obtaining a doctor's referral letter to begin hormone replacement therapy. It sparked a debate on what students who identify themselves as lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and queer (LGBTQ) are facing in schools.

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline

Photo: TODAY reader

description:
In a statement issued by the group alleged to have assembled illegally, it said that they were a group of students and supporters staging a peaceful demonstration to call on Education Minister Lawrence Wong to end discrimination against the LGBTQ+ community in schools.

The police said in a statement on Tuesday that the group outside MOE‚Äôs headquarters had allegedly gathered even though they did not have a permit to carry out the public assembly.

Yesterday (Jan 26) afternoon, images circulating on social media showed five young people outside the building along Buona Vista Drive holding up placards, a rainbow-coloured pride flag and a transgender flag with pale-pink and blue stripes.

Recently, an 18-year-old junior college student alleged that the ministry had prevented her from obtaining a doctor's referral letter to begin hormone replacement therapy. It sparked a debate on what students who identify themselves as lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and queer (LGBTQ) are facing in schools.

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline

Photo: TODAY reader

description:
Getting hurt in the line of duty. 

When a traffic police officer stopped Azhar Amin in his car along Geylang Road, the repeat drug offender gave a fake name and NRIC number.

When the policeman and a female passerby then tried to pull him out of the vehicle, Azhar stepped on the accelerator, dragging the uniformed officer about 30 to 40m along the road before driving off to Toa Payoh.

Azhar was wanted at the time, having failed to report for urine tests 21 times...

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

#singapore #crime #courts

description:
"It‚Äôs alright to be lost sometimes, we just have to give ourselves time to learn how to thrive," writes TODAY contributor Estella Zhang Qiming, a second-year business student at Peking University‚Äôs Guanghua School of Management.

She first went to study in Beijing in September 2019 and came back to Singapore for a semester break in January 2020. Due to the Covid-19 pandemic and closure of borders, she has remained in Singapore since and have been attending lessons online.

"Online classes provided me with the space needed to step back from the situation," she writes, as she realised that during her time in school, her focus was on her studies and little else.

What did she do in the past year, that has so enriched her life?
Find out, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

#student #singapore #covid_19 #elearning #onlineclasses #pku #pekinguniversity #guanghuaschoolofmanagement #distancelearning #sgstudents

description:
When messaging app WhatsApp‚Äôs new privacy policy sparked a global exodus from its services, Mr Darren Chin‚Äôs company ‚Äî a local tech firm ‚Äî decreed that its entire staff was to cease using the Facebook-owned platform for work.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve all been using WhatsApp for many years, but the company‚Äôs top management decided to ban it and we cannot say no,‚Äù said Mr Chin, 52. 

‚ÄúEveryone in the tech chat groups in my company switched to Signal, so I did so as well. I agree with the decision too: Data privacy is important to me,‚Äù the IT operations specialist told TODAY ‚Äî  ironically in an interview conducted over Facebook at his request.

Signal, as well as Telegram, are rival encrypted messaging apps that have surged in popularity amid the fiasco as an alternative to WhatsApp.

WhatsApp has since come forward to clarify that its new terms will not allow its parent company to access the app users' messages, and delayed its February deadline for users to accept the terms. But...

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

#whatsapp #signal #dataprivacy #privacypolicy #messagingapp #facebook #personaldata #personaldataprotection #socialmedia #thebigread #thebigreadtoday

description:
Will you stop using WhatsApp over privacy concerns? Comment below! 

The number of new users installing messaging app Signal every day is on track to cross one million, putting it closer to levels seen by larger rival WhatsApp, following an update to the Facebook-owned app's privacy policy.

About 810,000 users globally installed Signal on Sunday (Jan 10), nearly 18-fold compared with the download numbers on Jan 6, the day WhatsApp updated its privacy terms, according to data from research firm Apptopia.

WhatsApp's new privacy terms reserve the right to share user data, including location and phone number, with its parent Facebook and units such as Instagram and Messenger.

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

#signal #whatsapp #privacyplease #dataprivacy #messagingapp #userdata 

Photo: AFP

comments: And I'm still using sms

description:
The Government did not take the initiative to disclose that data from the TraceTogether application and token may be used for criminal investigations, revealing it after it was already used for a murder case, TODAY reader Pierce Yip said.

He writes: "Whatever the merits of the police using the data, the way the matter has been handled and presented to the public as a fait accompli leaves a bad taste in many mouths."

"Leaving aside the Government‚Äôs track record of adopting a relatively expansive view of what constitutes a ‚Äúserious offence‚Äù, how reassuring can the guarantee by Home Affairs Minister K Shanmugam be when previous ministerial assurances on the matter made just six months ago have now been so easily set aside?"

"Dr Balakrishnan rightly stressed the importance of trust and transparency in Parliament. This is why the Government‚Äôs decision not to make good on its word is most baffling for the non-cynical observer."

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

#tracetogethertoken #tracetogether #tracetogethertokenssg #singapore

comments: so many languages and he chose to speak facts

description:
Singapore writer Ng Yi-Sheng had been using the TraceTogether mobile application for months during the Covid-19 pandemic. He even carried the token out with him when it is not necessary to use both together, because just holding the token made him feel safe.

This week, the 40-year-old deleted the app and has started leaving his token at home, after learning that TraceTogether data could be used for criminal investigations.

Not that he had anything to hide, but because he felt betrayed, as he put it, by the trust he had placed in the Government‚Äôs earlier assurances that the data was used solely for contact-tracing purposes to combat coronavirus transmission.

When it was revealed in Parliament this week that the police can obtain TraceTogether data for criminal investigations under the Criminal Procedure Code (CPC), it set online conversations abuzz...

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

#tracetogethertoken #tracetogether #tracetogethertokenssg #personaldata #dataprivacy #contacttracing #contacttracers #singapore #covid_19

comments: If you didn't do anything wrong there is no need to be afraid üëå

comments: Our phones are private, the photos inside, the messages, and every other data are private too. But likewise the police can still obtain a warrant to access all the information inside when investigating a crime, so how is that any different from TT? It was never built to facilitate criminal investigations but in rare situations where the data can actually help catch criminals, I don‚Äôt see any problems with it. If you want drama, just watch the US news. Stop creating something out of nothing.

description:
TODAY contributor Sarah Ong Xinmin writes: "From the time I entered the Integrated Programme (IP) in River Valley High School, I had been on a steady journey towards completing my A-Level examination." 

"But in 2019, I decided to leave the IP and enrol for a nursing course at Nanyang Polytechnic (NYP). I am currently in my second year and I have never felt surer about pursuing my passion."

"Don‚Äôt get me wrong: After working really hard and scoring 255 for my Primary School Leaving Examination, I was excited to embark on my life in the IP track ‚Äî a six-year through-train programme that is offered only in 17 schools islandwide currently, targeting higher-performing students ‚Äì and the journey was nothing short of enriching."

"But, there came a point when I began to seriously question my choice in the IP.
Questions like ‚ÄúHow will these assessment books and worksheets help me eventually in my career?‚Äù came to mind and I struggled to find meaning in what I was studying...

Continue reading Sarah's story, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline

description:
TODAY contributor Sarah Ong Xinmin writes: "From the time I entered the Integrated Programme (IP) in River Valley High School, I had been on a steady journey towards completing my A-Level examination." 

"But in 2019, I decided to leave the IP and enrol for a nursing course at Nanyang Polytechnic (NYP). I am currently in my second year and I have never felt surer about pursuing my passion."

"Don‚Äôt get me wrong: After working really hard and scoring 255 for my Primary School Leaving Examination, I was excited to embark on my life in the IP track ‚Äî a six-year through-train programme that is offered only in 17 schools islandwide currently, targeting higher-performing students ‚Äì and the journey was nothing short of enriching."

"But, there came a point when I began to seriously question my choice in the IP.
Questions like ‚ÄúHow will these assessment books and worksheets help me eventually in my career?‚Äù came to mind and I struggled to find meaning in what I was studying...

Continue reading Sarah's story, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline

comments: It really isn‚Äôt that big of a deal lol. If you want to choose nursing IP isn‚Äôt the choice. Also, IP isn‚Äôt just offered to you, you need to go for rounds and rounds of interviews. And then get accepted and choose that you WANT to take up IP in the school. I mean, every year, there are people dropping out of IP for many reasons. And one of them is that you only realise that IP will not aid you in nursing at maybe Year 3 or 4, you‚Äôll need a diploma so an A level cert will not help. Thus dropping out. So it‚Äôs just about which path is best for an individual.

description:
This unusual hobby has helped Mr Peter Kiew, 72, through family problems and health issues.

While most commuters are bemused and elated at his works, some have their reservations. There have been commuters who accuse him of invading their privacy and even threaten to call the police.

‚ÄúI will just tell them, if you don‚Äôt like what I do, then I‚Äôll tear up the paper,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWhen people tell me such things, it goes into one ear and then out the other, I don‚Äôt let it bother me.‚Äù

It is the happiness of commuters that keeps him doing what he does. The moment he boards an MRT train, he springs to action, whipping out a sketchpad, pencil and eraser, before proceeding to methodically sketch the commuters around him, one by one.

Once the 72-year-old is done with each sketch, he will offer the artwork to the commuter free of charge. He started this hobby in 2014, and that he hardly takes rest days.

TODAY accompanied Mr Kiew as he sketched commuters from Bishan to Jurong East. Click on the link in bio @todayonline to read on.

#singapore #sgart #sgartist #sgsketch #sgsketcher #art #sketch #sketching #mrtart

description:
Some of the best home-made nosh worth ordering this holiday season. 

1. FiftyGramss @fiftygramss 
This business specialises in unpretentious, rich, gooey desserts ‚Äî think burnt cheesecakes, Nutella brownies, and an incredibly dramatic chocolate cake that comes enrobed in flowy chocolate ganache. That last part is doled out theatrically at the table: You pour the molten ganache over the cake which comes collared with a ring of plastic. As you lift the plastic, the dark pool of ganache cascades over the cake.

2. BraidBrad @braidbrad 
Only one thing is on offer at this little Instagram bakery: babka, gorgeous Jewish laminated enriched bread (brioche in this case) with crusty tops, rolled with luscious fillings like chocolate, caramel and nuts. Flavours include Nutella, and a nutty Cashew Caramel. 

3. One Sweet Bite @xonesweetbitex 
Neatly-made, pretty kuehs such as Pulut Inti, Kueh Salat, Ondeh Ondeh, and Lemper Ayam - an Indonesian snack of sticky rice stuffed with spicy chicken floss, wrapped in banana leaves and steamed. 

For the full list, head to the link in bio @todayonline 

#homebaker #sghomebaker #sghomecooking #sgeats #sgfoodie #sgfoodstagram #sgbakes #sgbakery #sgbakers

comments: Wow I didnt know the cruise ships where still running
description:
The Royal Caribbean cruise ship passenger who tested positive for Covid-19 is an 83-year-old man who reported to the ship‚Äôs onboard medical centre with diarrhoea.

He had undergone testing before boarding the cruise and tested negative.

The ship, Quantum of the Seas, returned to Singapore this morning. The remaining passengers and crew will remain on board, in their rooms, until contact tracing is complete, STB said. 

‚ÄúThey will all undergo mandatory Covid-19 testing before leaving the terminal, as per the regular post-arrival protocols. In the meantime, they are being given regular updates and meals are provided directly to their rooms.‚Äù 

The cruise set off from Singapore on Monday and was to have returned to shore tomorrow morning. 

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline

description:
She allegedly pinched one of the maid‚Äôs biceps using her toes when the woman was massaging her, and hit the other maid when she was helping her put on her socks. 

Tan Lee Hoon, 56, lives on Paradise Island, one of the five man-made islands at Sentosa Cove on Sentosa Island.

She is accused of voluntarily causing hurt to Filipino nationals Lizardo Joan Lozares, 33, and Jenefer Arangote Vegafria, 39, at her Sentosa Cove home in 2018. She is challenging all of her eight charges. 

The charges allege that she had hurt Ms Lozares by kicking her chest, smacking her head, and hitting her torso with a stick. She is also said to have pinched Ms Vegafria‚Äôs chest, stomach, left arm, right bicep and right thigh.

The court heard that four days after the police first showed up at Tan's home to begin investigations, they returned to the home to retrieve footage from surveillance cameras installed here. However, they found that the hard drive was missing...

description:
A passenger on a Royal Caribbean cruise to nowhere has tested positive for Covid-19.

The passenger was immediately isolated and all close contacts of the passenger have tested negative, Ms Annie Chang, director of cruise at the Singapore Tourism Board (STB), said in a statement today. 

‚ÄúEmergency response plans have been activated according to guidelines, including immediate isolation of close contacts, contact tracing and deep cleaning of the ship,‚Äù she added.

TODAY‚Äôs reporter, who is at Marina Bay Cruise Centre, saw the ship dock at the centre at about 8.20am. The ship returned to Singapore so that passengers may disembark and receive medical support if necessary.

Since last Thursday, Royal Caribbean has been operating cruises to nowhere from Singapore ‚Äî the second cruise company to do so after Genting Cruise Lines.

‚ÄúEmergency response plans have been activated according to guidelines, including immediate isolation of close contacts, contact tracing and deep cleaning of the ship,‚Äù she added.

TODAY‚Äôs reporter, who is at Marina Bay Cruise Centre, saw the ship dock at the centre at about 8.20am. The ship returned to Singapore so that passengers may disembark and receive medical support if necessary.

Since last Thursday, Royal Caribbean has been operating cruises to nowhere from Singapore ‚Äî the second cruise company to do so after Genting Cruise Lines. 

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

#cruisetonowhere #royalcaribbean #royalcaribbeancruise @royalcaribbeansg #covid_19

description:
Picking up more than just dust and dirt in your home. 

Apart from performing its usual functions, your robot vacuum cleaner could also be picking up private conversations. 

Computer scientists from the National University of Singapore (NUS) have demonstrated how a common robot vacuum cleaner and its built-in light detection and ranging (Lidar) sensor could be used to "spy" on private conversations, the university said yesterday. 

‚ÄúThe system was able to detect the digits being spoken aloud, which could constitute a victim‚Äôs credit card or bank account numbers. Music clips from television shows could potentially disclose the victim‚Äôs viewing preferences or political orientation,‚Äù said NUS.

To prevent Lidars from being misused, what are those with robot vacuum cleaners advised to do?

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

Photo: NUS @nus_singapore 

#nus #nuscomputing #nusschoolofcomputing #computerscience #robotvacuumcleaner #lidar #lidarsensor #privacyplease

Computer scientists from the National University of Singapore (NUS) have demonstrated how a common robot vacuum cleaner and its built-in light detection and ranging (Lidar) sensor could be used to "spy" on private conversations, the university said yesterday. 

‚ÄúThe system was able to detect the digits being spoken aloud, which could constitute a victim‚Äôs credit card or bank account numbers. Music clips from television shows could potentially disclose the victim‚Äôs viewing preferences or political orientation,‚Äù said NUS.

To prevent Lidars from being misused, what are those with robot vacuum cleaners advised to do?

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

Photo: NUS @nus_singapore 

#nus #nuscomputing #nusschoolofcomputing #computerscience #robotvacuumcleaner #lidar #lidarsensor #privacyplease

description:
Buy an apartment, get (fill in the bracket) for free. 

Lawrence Wong @ohohlawrence is back in Singapore, and he's been busy supervising the renovation of his new home.

Home for the 32-year-old in Singapore used to be a condo located in the western part of Singapore, but the Story of Yanxi Palace star has since sold that unit to buy a landed property.‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã

And, judging by an Instagram Story update on December 3, the person who bought his apartment had one special request. According to the actor, the buyer had printed out pictures of Lawrence and passed them along to the property agent, hoping to score some autographs from Lawrence.

Yes, he signed them. A buy-a-condo-unit, get-autographed-photos-by-actor-for-free deal. 

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

Photos: @ohohlawrence / Instagram

And, judging by an Instagram Story update on December 3, the person who bought his apartment had one special request. According to the actor, the buyer had printed out pictures of Lawrence and passed them along to the property agent, hoping to score some autographs from Lawrence.

Yes, he signed them. A buy-a-condo-unit, get-autographed-photos-by-actor-for-free deal. 

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

Photos: @ohohlawrence / Instagram

description:
Not long now! 

By December, it will be compulsory to use the TraceTogether mobile application or token to check in at venues such as workplaces, schools, malls as well as food and beverage outlets under the Government's plan to further reopen the economy.

At these venues, people will not be able to check in by scanning their identification cards or SafeEntry QR codes with their phones, the Smart Nation and Digital Government Office said in a statement yesterday.

Instead, they will have to either use the TraceTogether app to scan a QR code at the premises or have the staff there scan the QR code found on their token.

Currently, only the use of SafeEntry is compulsory.

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

#trace #tracker #tracetogether #covid_19 #corona #covid #government #sg #app

comments: Yes ,it is painful, you did not do any wrong, it's not easy , stay strong and move on
description:
His sentencing day turned out to be the day of his release from jail. 

The day he was sentenced, Tan Tian Chye, 66, cried and thanked the judge, prosecutors and his lawyers. He had killed his mentally ill daughter in 2018 after she pointed a knife at him. 

He was released from prison on the day he was sentenced to 2 years and 9 months‚Äô jail, having been in remand since 2018. 

His family is glad to have him home.

In a statement sent to TODAY through the man‚Äôs lawyers, the family wrote: ‚ÄúWhile we are extremely grateful for the messages of support and comfort from members of the public, we ask now for privacy and the space for us to heal as a family.‚Äô‚Äô

‚Äò‚ÄôWe hope to close this painful chapter in our lives, so that we may move on and look towards the future.‚Äù

More about this story, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline

description:
The men, aged between 19 and 38, were first detected on Tuas reclaimed land by the Police Coast Guard‚Äôs surveillance systems on Friday at about 8.30pm, said the Singapore Police Force yesterday.

The four men were observed to have jumped off an unnumbered boat into the waters off Tuas reclaimed land before swimming towards the shoreline.

Coast Guard officers, together with personnel from the Jurong Police Division, Gurkha Contingent, Special Operations Command and Home Team Unmanned Aerial Vehicles Unit were deployed to intercept the men, the police said.

The men were arrested within five hours of being detected, and were handed over to the Immigration and Checkpoints Authority for further investigations. 

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

Photo: Police Coast Guard

The four men were observed to have jumped off an unnumbered boat into the waters off Tuas reclaimed land before swimming towards the shoreline.

Coast Guard officers, together with personnel from the Jurong Police Division, Gurkha Contingent, Special Operations Command and Home Team Unmanned Aerial Vehicles Unit were deployed to intercept the men, the police said.

The men were arrested within five hours of being detected, and were handed over to the Immigration and Checkpoints Authority for further investigations. 

Read on, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

Photo: Police Coast Guard

description:
The set-up was elaborate. 

The cheating students had wearable Bluetooth devices attached onto their bodies, and had on skin-coloured, in-ear earphones before going into the exam centres. These devices were linked to mobile phones concealed under the students‚Äô clothing.

Two accomplices registered themselves as private candidates, and either of them sat for an exam paper with a hidden iPhone affixed to their chests.

During the exam, they used the video-calling application FaceTime to broadcast the exam papers back to other accomplices stationed at the tuition agency.

Once the accomplices had the answers to the exam questions, they called the students individually and read out the answers to them.

The students, who received the instructions through their earphones, would then write down the answers. They were told to cough if they could not hear any of the answers clearly so that the answer could be repeated back to them.

How did the students get caught, and the scheme come to light?
Find out, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

Photos: @todayonline

The cheating students had wearable Bluetooth devices attached onto their bodies, and had on skin-coloured, in-ear earphones before going into the exam centres. These devices were linked to mobile phones concealed under the students‚Äô clothing.

Two accomplices registered themselves as private candidates, and either of them sat for an exam paper with a hidden iPhone affixed to their chests.

During the exam, they used the video-calling application FaceTime to broadcast the exam papers back to other accomplices stationed at the tuition agency.

Once the accomplices had the answers to the exam questions, they called the students individually and read out the answers to them.

The students, who received the instructions through their earphones, would then write down the answers. They were told to cough if they could not hear any of the answers clearly so that the answer could be repeated back to them.

How did the students get caught, and the scheme come to light?
Find out, when you click on the link in bio @todayonline 

Photos: @todayonline

description:
Shortly after face masks were made mandatory in places like shopping malls to minimise the spread of Covid-19, Sun Szu-Yen and her 10-year-old son were stopped at Ion Orchard mall for failing to wear them.

Sun wrapped her scarf around her mouth, but was not allowed into the mall. She then pulled another scarf out of her bag and indicated that she would use it as a mask.

When she was again denied entry, she sneezed in the guard‚Äôs direction and said: ‚ÄúYou get it? You get it already!‚Äù She also took her passport from her bag and said: ‚ÄúI am China, I am Taiwan.‚Äù

The guard asked her to leave but she started to scribble over her particulars on the mall's contact tracing form, so they could no longer be seen. When the guard tried to stop her, Sun said: ‚ÄúShut up‚Äù and ‚ÄúDo your work‚Äù before leaving.

Separately, on June 4 last year, Sun threw several items out of her condominium window as she was feeling stressed and frustrated.

A security guard at the condominium told Sun to calm down, but she refused and shouted that they could call the police. The guard proceeded to do so.

More details, in the link in bio @todayonline

comments: Well then go home we don‚Äôt need you here if you‚Äôre just gonna shit on us

description:
Shortly after face masks were made mandatory in places like shopping malls to minimise the spread of Covid-19, Sun Szu-Yen and her 10-year-old son were stopped at Ion Orchard mall for failing to wear them.

Sun wrapped her scarf around her mouth, but was not allowed into the mall. She then pulled another scarf out of her bag and indicated that she would use it as a mask.

When she was again denied entry, she sneezed in the guard‚Äôs direction and said: ‚ÄúYou get it? You get it already!‚Äù She also took her passport from her bag and said: ‚ÄúI am China, I am Taiwan.‚Äù

The guard asked her to leave but she started to scribble over her particulars on the mall's contact tracing form, so they could no longer be seen. When the guard tried to stop her, Sun said: ‚ÄúShut up‚Äù and ‚ÄúDo your work‚Äù before leaving.

Separately, on June 4 last year, Sun threw several items out of her condominium window as she was feeling stressed and frustrated.

A security guard at the condominium told Sun to calm down, but she refused and shouted that they could call the police. The guard proceeded to do so.

More details, in the link in bio @todayonline

description:
Shortly after face masks were made mandatory in places like shopping malls to minimise the spread of Covid-19, Sun Szu-Yen and her 10-year-old son were stopped at Ion Orchard mall for failing to wear them.

Sun wrapped her scarf around her mouth, but was not allowed into the mall. She then pulled another scarf out of her bag and indicated that she would use it as a mask.

When she was again denied entry, she sneezed in the guard‚Äôs direction and said: ‚ÄúYou get it? You get it already!‚Äù She also took her passport from her bag and said: ‚ÄúI am China, I am Taiwan.‚Äù

The guard asked her to leave but she started to scribble over her particulars on the mall's contact tracing form, so they could no longer be seen. When the guard tried to stop her, Sun said: ‚ÄúShut up‚Äù and ‚ÄúDo your work‚Äù before leaving.

Separately, on June 4 last year, Sun threw several items out of her condominium window as she was feeling stressed and frustrated.

A security guard at the condominium told Sun to calm down, but she refused and shouted that they could call the police. The guard proceeded to do so.

More details, in the link in bio @todayonline

description:
''I think enough time has transpired for the entire F&B industry, as well as for diners, to understand what the rules are and to comply with them," said Education Minister Lawrence Wong.

The authorities will no longer issue warnings to food-and-beverage (F&B) establishments that flout any safe management regulations. Instead, enforcement action will be taken against them, even for first-time offenders.

This is to tackle those who persistently break the rules and depending on the severity of the offence, these enforcement actions will include fines or the closure of the premises.

More details, in the link in bio @todayonline

description:
The Korean actor has been staying out of the public eye since his high profile divorce from his Descendants Of The Sun co-star Song Hye Kyo last June.

Naturally, netizens were delighted to see a video of him in action, while on a staycay with his family. 

At the very high SES The South Cape Spa & Suite, no less. 

The resort's villas reportedly cost up to 10mil won (S$11.5K) a night, and are so exclusive that visitors are guaranteed privacy during their stay.

To see the video of SJK playing with his nephew, head to the link in bio @todayonline 

Pix: PBE Media

description:
While there has been an uptick in community transmissions since Phase 2 of the circuit breaker exit, this does not constitute a second wave, said Health Minister Gan Kim Yong, who added that the numbers generally remain low and stable. 

However, Mr Gan said that what is of great concern is the number of symptomatic unlinked community infections. 

Mr Lawrence Wong, who co-chairs the multi-ministry task force, added that the Government cannot rule out the possibility of having to impose additional restrictions or even implementing a second nationwide lockdown. 

Read more in the #linkinbio

description:

Using FaceTime, carefully concealed mobile phones and Bluetooth devices, they attended the exams, broadcasting the exam papers to their accomplices who called students to read the answers out to them.

description:
Parties continued on the campaign trail on Friday (July 3), speaking to voters across Singapore ahead of the General Election. TODAY's journalists captured some of these moments.

1. Dr Tan Cheng Bock introducing PSP candidate Choo Shaun Ming to Chua Chu Kang residents at a coffeeshop at Teck Whye Lane. 

2. PAP‚Äôs secretary-general Lee Hsien Loong met residents in Ang Mo Kio and Yio Chu Kang, where he joined the party‚Äôs candidate Yip Hon Weng on the campaign trail. 

3. WP's Sylvia Lim, Pritam Singh and new face Tan Chen Chen meet a resident‚Äôs pet parrot during a walkabout near Punggol MRT station. 

4. PAP's new face Edward Chia on a walkbout at Bangkit Road. 

5. SDP's Paul Tambyah greets a resident during his walkabout at Pending Road. 

6. PAP's Dr Vivian Balakrishnan speaking with residents at Bangkit Road. 

7. WP's Sylvia Lim, Pritam Singh and Tan Chen Chen, who is the candidate contesting for Punggol West SMC, on a walkabout near Soo Teck LRT station. 

8. PAP‚Äôs Lee Hsien Loong with fellow party candidates greeting residents on the campaign trail.

9. PSP chief Tan Cheng Bock with candidates for Chua Chu Kang GRC Choo Shaun Ming and Francis Yuen taking a selfie with a resident at Blk 9 Teck Whye Lane. 

10. Mr Lee Hsien Loong and Mr Yip Hon Weng sat down together to chat about the new PAP candidate‚Äôs campaign so far. 

üì∏: Ooi Boon Keong, Nuria Ling, Lena Loke, Justin Ong

description:
‚ÄúIt is starting to look like a global pandemic everywhere around the world‚Äù, at which point it will not be possible to shut Singapore out from the world, National Development Minister Lawrence Wong said on Friday (March 6) at a press conference by the Multi-Ministry Task Force that is tackling the virus outbreak, which he co-chairs.

He was addressing a question about the continued relevance of border controls and travel restrictions. ‚ÄúWe do need to do more within our own community in Singapore to slow the spread of the virus,‚Äù Mr Wong added.
